plist.p: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen. If we're all settled down, welcome to RBS' 2008 Annual Results. Whilst I've only been Chairman for a few weeks now, I'm acutely conscious that 2008 was an extraordinarily difficult year for the business, for our customers, for employees and of course the shareholders, public and private, who put very large amounts of money, new capital, into the business in the course of the year. And of course we're particularly grateful today to the continuing support we have from the government, from UK taxpayers, that support which now secures our financial stability and underpins our future.

We're going to be a little bit longer today because we've got three things to discuss. Guy will go through the financial results in the customary way, although I think it's fair to say there's some fairly uncustomary figures and issues in there that we don't want to see repeated. And then critically today of course, Stephen is going to go through the conclusions of the strategic review that he and his team have been working on in recent months; and then we'll – Stephen will give our first public thoughts on the asset protection scheme announced this morning.

We're going to start with Stephen and since we've got a lot to do we'll get on with it straightaway. If I can make one request is that your mobiles are completely turned off please, not just on mute. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Philip. Good morning everyone. We unconventionally, as Philip mentioned, thought I would go first so that whilst you're awake you will hear from me and then the fireworks and the numbers will give you a jolt towards the end. You should also have in packs extensive appendices and it's been our attempt to make a significant stride forward from RBS' previous position in terms of financial transparency. We want to be at the forefront of financial transparency and so we are open to any suggestions in the future as to what more we can do that would be helpful.

So rather than, if you like, talk about the business backward looking its seems sensible to forward look as much as we could this morning, and the key task ahead of us is to execute the strategy that we're laying out to restructure RBS, to return it to being one of the world's premier financial institutions. We'll be anchored in the UK but serving customers globally. Clearly we need to rebuild shareholder value, clearly we need to allow the government to get out of our hair and get their money back, and that could only be accomplished if we reinforce leadership in our markets, but are disciplined in the way we do that and that's what we're getting on with.

I wanted to just give this next slide a perspective because I think that moving back, if you like, to the October wake up call and recapitalization that we're required and may others required, there are an essential set of building blocks without which we can't go on the path of recovery and I think that we are pushing those building blocks in place and many of them are indeed after today in place against which to execute. Clearly, recapitalization and government support on funding have been a very, very important component of that, as the management and Board changes as well; understanding our problems and presenting them and of course the most comprehensive version of that, again, is in the financial statement presented today.

We then announced today the new strategy, the roadmap, around which to unite our people, our resources and to tell you where we are planning to go. But of course since the early years of the execution of that strategy are going to be fraught with uncertainty, the stability that the asset protection scheme affords or improves is an equally essential bit of allowing us to be able to execute that strategic plan. And then, of course, there's the unmanageable bit, which is exactly how many headwinds are we going to face and with what volatility from the market. But essentially, after today our job becomes execution; that's no small job, but that's what it becomes.

And the strategy which I will be going through today in headlines is putting over 20% of our funded assets into a non-core division to work off over the next three to five years, cutting the cost base; obviously the asset protection scheme we'll talk about, and then all of the rest of our business will have extensive restructuring ranging from GBM where there is the most work to do. We will cut, we plan to cut 45% out of the capital base of GBM in restructuring it to what we believe will be a very strong and successful investment bank on its revised mandate, and then clearly a substantive change to all the rest of our businesses, and alongside that the management and processes. And we've been pretty busy to date, I won't go through this slide, it's not been a relaxing few months and it won't be yet, but I think we are, one-by-one, ticking off a lot of things.

Now, just to say on the results and Guy will obviously go through the numbers, but it is unambiguous bad results both in terms of the headline and in terms of the loss, even pre-goodwill. I do think though that it is important, first of all, obviously to put into context that that's true of a number of other banks. I think we still only rank tenth in the lead table of shame in terms of losses. But within these results, actually the vast majority of our business was profitable. Even in GBM where the losses were concentrated there were £10 billion of revenues, nearly an all time record before the concentrated, more specific areas that gave a rise to very large losses were recorded. And that's important not just if you like to give credit to the past, which is important, but also to give a sense of assurance that we are not building on sand here, we are building on rock. What we need to do is sweep away the sand that currently lies over some of that rock.

So, what we are trying hard not to do, because it's unproductive, is to get into the blame game for the past. There are plenty of people who are spending their time doing that without you needing to hear it from me. But I think it is very important to just think a little bit about the issues that got us where we are because unless we correct for them we have risk going forward, but also if you identify them it's understandable what you don't need to correct for and puts the strategy in context. And as I say, I don't want to belabor it, but these six areas in my view are the areas where – which we need to address in order to correct what went wrong.

In addition to that, we clearly need to change the company to suit the way that markets are likely to change and those are two components of the strategic plan. Leverage is clear. The ABN AMRO acquisition, in a sense, has ingredients from all the other boxes here. I say strategy, I think the strategy is vital for companies, not just because it gives you a purposeful roadmap, but I think it makes you think more about your markets, about your position in the markets, the capacity for growth and therefore, if you are trying to do things with your business, the markets you operate in won't support; you'll make mistakes. And whether it be the growth rate that markets will support, whether it be the strength of your competitive position and therefore the likely quality of the business you do and so on, founding things in clear strategy as opposed to, if you like, day-to-day profit growth and opportunism will be a very, very important base. I think it's a quality of business.

Risk controls, I suspect, go without saying. Profit focus, we'll look – our job is to make profits and our job is to grow profits and there should be no ambiguity about that, and unless we do that well we'll be seen to have failed. But there is, I think, a risk often, frankly, encouraged by audiences that public companies have of making that a solitary goal and you have to think very carefully about how your profits are being made, with what resources, with what risks and make sure that there is a full suite of targets and management aspirations from which profit derives.

And then clearly, if you like management processes, the culture of the firm, the bench strength of the management, the empowerment of the businesses around their strategic targets, all of these are issues that we will address and strengthen and are doing. So in conceptualizing the strategic plan, we were really working both top down and bottom up. And the strategic plan that we have is, if you like, the resolution of those.

I set out for you when I last addressed you on joining three months ago five tests that I put forward if you like, as the bottom up tests for every business we have to meet through the strategic plan process. Top tier competitive positions, from which I think quality profits derive, 15% plus ROE which is where I believe we will get back to. How many years? I don't know the answer to that, but we will get back to after the downturn.

Proportionate use of balance sheet risk and funding, incredibly important. Organic growth potential and that doesn't just mean taking a swipe at acquisitions, but it does mean that if your business is to grow organically you have to work them harder. You have to invest in them. The management capacity is stretched in doing that and so on. And then, of course, connectivity within the Group. We can't have fiefdoms. We have to have businesses that work together.

And so these are the five tests against which every one of our businesses has been measured and the plans have been developed and the things that we're discarding have been discarded. But they have to fit the top down, and I think the key disciplines, or we could make this more complex, we need to return to standalone strength. And for now I see that as AA category ratings standalone today. We benefit from those, courtesy of government support. We need to benefit from those standalone. Guy, at the end of his presentation, will give some indication of what we think that might be in terms of balance sheet and capital, although of course that's a voyage of discovery for many. And profitability I set out the targets top down as well as bottom up and obviously business mix where we are not in any way saying we won't take risk. If you don't take risk you don't make money in financial services, but obviously that has to be more balanced than it was before.

So the first, if you like, step of the plan is to identify those things that we believe are not capable of meeting my five strategic tests and initially labeling them our non-core division and by doing that and managing that division separately, albeit on a matrix basis within the Group, we free the rest of the Group, both visually and in terms of management effort, to do its own restructuring to meet our GBM business targets.

And I think that you can see that throughout the plan what we have to do is basically come up with what I would describe as a self-help plan. There is not at the moment an active M&A market that ascribes good values to financial services assets. It would be nice if there was a wonderful rabbit to pull out of a hat that way, but there isn't. That may change, and as a matter of management philosophy, there is no business that we will be irrational with in terms of value. If someone wants to pay more for business than it's worth we must always, regards that business, be open to that. However, we're not relying on that, we have to chart, we believe, a self-help plan and any inorganic opportunities to short cut that will be what they will be.

Let me give you some more dimensions around the non-core division. We did announce, by the way, this morning separately that we have hired or rehired Nathan Bostock, who was at Abbey recently as Finance Director, but he ran the portfolio business unit for me at Abbey in the early 2000s and so he has done this before albeit on a different scale and he will be heading up the division in which is the non-core division for us.

It's important to note that the non-core division contains a bunch of different things. It does contain a bunch of our stressed assets, in fact many of our stressed assets, but it also contains assets that are not stressed but simply are non-strategic relative to the five tests that I set out. It is a mixture of portfolios, individual assets and businesses and it comes in large part from our wholesale businesses, but not exclusively and I'll show that on the next slide. Unfortunately, because of the liquidity and distressed nature of markets for assets, we can't, with confidence, chart the speed of sell-down of these businesses and these assets or indeed the costs. And one of the major benefits of the asset protection scheme is to allow us to do it with a higher likely end NPV than if we are under pressure to do it very, very fast because of the capital risk involved. But we clearly can't give that forecast. What we will do, obviously, is report regularly against it, but so the objective in selling it down is to sell it down purposefully, but with the best eye on NPV of outcome that we can have.

You'll see the broad financial parameters on the right hand side of the slide; and just to give you some sense of where these assets come from geographically and through our divisions divided into the derivative assets, which are in the lighter shading, and the balance sheet funded assets, we give this breakdown. There are other breakdowns that we will give, but I would ask you for some patience. We've been going at break-neck speeds to come up with this plan. There are many details that still in the next two or three months will need to be worked out. There are also a whole bunch of human sensitivities and so we may not be as forthcoming on detailed disclosure about this as you would like until the summer.

What I can now do, in a sense having just given you the dimensions of the non-core business there, is move on, if you like, to our ongoing businesses. And I'm going to spend time slightly strangely on this because I will spend not very much time on the businesses that, if you like, need the least surgery or have the least questions around them, and more time on the ones which I know, if you like, are newsworthy; but that is not in any way to suggest that that's the portion of importance.

So clearly, as I've mentioned already, the biggest changes that we need to execute are in our investment banking business where we plan to take 45% out. But it's important to note that we believe that there is a good future for this business. We have top tier positions in a number of key customer franchises, liquid markets, and we believe that we can make a good living out of those that they will be complementary, that they can have risk characteristics that will pave their way; and that we can have a very successful business as part of the Group on a significantly smaller scale overall, but on a big scale in the areas in which we choose to compete. And we set out on this slide some of the parameters around that.

And giving you a few more details on this next slide, dividing if you like, between core businesses, every business we have needs to do some things to strengthen and improve. Non-core businesses where we will substantially exit, and then what we call restructured core businesses in the middle where they will remain very important businesses for us, but need particularly heavy changes or surgery in order to regain the risk and return characteristics and the, if you like, the centering around customer franchises that we require.

And geographically, as you all know one of the consequences of the ABN acquisition was that we became extremely diverse in geography, but the vast majority of those geographies we were actually fairly small and marginal players in. And in a different world where we need to husband our resources, where we need to pay attention to the places we can definitely be winners, that investment profile is not sustainable. And so as a consequence there will be a significant reduction in the number of countries in which we have a presence. And in a number of countries our presence will be significantly reduced in order to make sure we can be strong, meaningful market leaders in our core countries. That doesn't mean to say we won't be global. We will be global, but you do not need to be in every country to be global; and it's better to be meaningful in lesser countries that to be spread thin, and that's at heart what this slide is trying to say.

Let me move off GBM to our U.S. retail and commercial business, which I think has attracted, if you like, lots of attention and thought. It is our belief that this business can be restructured in a way that makes it an attractive part of our Group. It is also our belief that in any event today there is not a value accretive alternative to that strategy, although that won't always be the case. Citizens does have strong market leading positions in the attractive markets of the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic in the United States. It is, relative to other U.S. retail commercial banks, low risk. Now at the moment that doesn't mean absolutely low risk, that's a relative statement. And it does have, and will have in restructured form, very attractive funding characteristics being largely deposit funded, in a way that improves the overall Group balance as well.

Nevertheless, we have major things that we have to do to make Citizens what it can be. In particular, we are going to draw back from a whole range of, if you like, incursions that have been made outside the core footprint geographically of Citizens both in terms of branches, but in particular in terms of individual lines, and credit cards and also loans and dealer finance and things like that. Secondly, we have a major restructuring to do in cost base and investment to do. Citizens, ironically, has been starved of technological investment in a number of ways which partly makes it inefficient, but partly means that the retail network, for example, is not operating as well as it should in terms of cross-sells and revenues.

The retail area we need to particularly revitalize, both as a revenue generator and as a funding generator. Our risk portfolios have been growing faster than deposits and we need to peel back on those and peel back out of footprint lending. We believe that if we do all of that we have tough targets for Citizens, not just the return targets and the market leadership targets that we have for all our businesses, but we need to regain a one-to-one ratio, which would be typical of U.S. banks, but we don't have in Citizens in terms of funding to deposits. We need to retain the below average risk profile for its markets and prove that we can grow it organically, which has not been the case in the past, although other banks in the same markets do grow organically, and therefore, we believe we can. And the connectivity with the rest of the Group, both in terms of use of products, in terms of personnel interchange, in terms of shared platforms is dramatically increasing as we speak. So we think that if we do all these things to Citizens, that Citizens will be valuable, attractive, meet our tests both as a holder and as an asset to the Group.

Now summarizing, if you like, the other businesses, every one of our other businesses, which clearly mostly lie now in the UK, have got major things that we want to do to them in order to enhance their prospects of meeting my five business tests; all to do with costs, to do with risk concentrations, to do with funding and balance sheet balance. There are some areas where there are more fundamental issues we need to confront. For example, retail banking, I think for the industry in the UK has got big issues. Those issues arise clearly from low interest rates, although hopefully that's cyclical. They arise from the various regulatory attacks on products like PPI and overdraft charging. And I do think that the retail banking model in the UK will need to undergo substantial change: the ways in which money can be made; the cost bases that can be supported; in our case looking also at the geographic footprint. There's a lot of work to do here, I think, for all banks and for us going forward.

Our market shares clearly are going to be hard to enhance because they're very, very good, although it may be with Lloyds and HBOS combination may make some market share easier to pick up if there's disruption in that area. Clearly, our new lending commitments in support of the government are importantly executed through retail and corporate and commercial.

And covering the other three business areas of the Group on this next slide, I mean Ulster Bank, of course, in effect is part of the UK both as it relates to Northern Ireland, but obviously with the important Irish presence. It shares the UK infrastructure and many of the products, but clearly the island of Ireland has a very major set of economic challenges which are further exacerbated by the commercial property and residential property concentrations that we and all others in Ireland have and a major restructuring of that business is required, although it ultimately will meet the five tests and in effect is an extension of what we do in the UK, albeit under a different brand. We are engaged in quite a radical set of actions there including the closure of the First Active brand, which is part of the goodwill write-off that we announced.

Insurance, I think we went through, if you like, a very public debate. It's a great business. There was an issue about whether it was worth more to others than to us. For now, that's demonstrably not the case. We can make it still better and there's lots of work around to do that.

And then GTS, which we sort of report separately, but really isn't a separate business because it feeds off the back of the client relationships that we have in all our other businesses and the capital that's deployed there. Nevertheless, a very high quality, high ROE, cash generative, funding generative business that which we need to continue to roll out, albeit the global ambitions of which will clearly be slowed a little bit by the global moves that we're making in other businesses.

And, if you like, spread across the top of all the business specific actions we have will be a whole range of changes to management process and culture, which are all about addressing the issues that have arisen in the past, making sure that we are one of the best managed banks out there. None of this is rocket science. None of this is inventing something that hasn't been done before, that which is why I'm confident we can do it; it just takes time.

Expenses, clearly there's lots of work to do on expenses and all banks in the world have a fast changing marketplace against which to aim efficiency and so we don't know whether this will be the last word or not. But in addition to eliminating the expenses associated with the non-core division we've set ourselves a target to cut out more than £2.5 billion from our costs over the next three years. The important provisos are: that's constant exchange rates; half a billion of that is the remaining fag end not yet delivered of the ABN synergies, so you could say it's really an incremental 2 billion; and there will be restructuring charges taken over the next three years to pay for that. We're obviously still working through the details, so we give a range of possible restructuring charge for that and I don't yet have a spread over in which year they will occur. And it's also important to note, as I say, this does not include cost saves from business exits. It does also not include the effect of inflation, if there is any, in the next three years. That's the joy ahead of us, of course; any movements on incentive pay or more new projects if there are any. But nevertheless, a substantive body of work across every one of our businesses and a necessary one.

Let me turn now, if you like, to the asset protection scheme and a number of my colleagues have not had a lot of sleep for a number of weeks and have done an unbelievable, stellar job in grappling with this sort of slippery octopus of a process in coming up with what has been announced overnight. The facts are that we have, if you like, headlined or outlined terms for the asset protection scheme, but there is not a definitive agreement; there are lots of details still to work through. This needs to be put to our shareholders among other things. And obviously we can't make a full recommendation to our shareholders until the details are worked out. So what we're saying is we are minded to go into it. We believe it is in shareholders' interest, but these details are very important and it's not a decision to take lightly, because this is not a free; there are many difficult aspects to this for shareholders and hopefully I'll take you through some of them as we go along.

But clearly what we have been setting out to do, our objectives in engaging with the government in this, has been to do something that enhances our financial strength. Obviously, shareholders will have nothing if our customers and counterparties are not confident in dealing with us even if conditions get much worse than they are today. Reducing risk to shareholders, which has been, if you like, a predominant theme of all financial services equities in recent months and weeks. Clearly, the price tag for that is increased commitment in the UK; that, in many respects though, is a welcome price tag. We have leading market shares.

We can do great business in the UK. We remain free to price and risk assess as we would wish; but if we have the wherewithal to capitalize when others are pulling back in our core market, that ought to be attractive to shareholders over time in its own right. And clearly, to the extent that stability and insurance allows us to run off the non-core division more profitability for shareholders, and I believe this does, that's good as well.

So against, if you like, those objectives going into it, this is the opportunity that we have should we participate in the scheme as we intend. We have an outline agreement for a pool of 300 billion of assets made up approximately of 225 billion, if you like, funded assets on the balance sheet; 44 billion of committed undrawn lines at the counterparties where we're worried about future stress; 33 billion of mark-to-market possible future exposure on derivatives; and underneath that, approximately 160 billion of risk-weighted assets. Although, we need to be careful with all of these, because all of these portfolios will have a fair amount of additional refinement between now and the scheme becoming effective. So anything we say now may be off a few percentage points either way. But I think, in big picture terms, we'll be right.

And to give you a sense, this is a bigger, a significantly bigger scheme than we planned for or were even seeking, but you can conceptually think of it as two things. We are trying to ensure against our most stressed assets in order to protect the stability of the bank in a bad case. We are trying to make room for additional UK lending, which is the price tag. And in order to do that, we need a bigger scheme, which ensures a bunch of ongoing good assets if you like. I mean they'll all be subject to stress in a downturn, but it's that extra size that allows us to pony up on the lending whilst keeping the financial stability that was the goal of it. And so that's why approximately 55% of these assets are ones that you'll find in our non-core and the balance are ones that you'll find in our core businesses, mostly in the UK, in terms of the ongoing lending.

And now just going through, if you like, the pricing; risk-weighted asset relief, the FSA has put out a ruling that gives us risk-weighted asset relief in respect to these assets caveated by two things. We keep a 10% strip of risks, so we obviously have the risk-weighted assets associated with that. And then there are risk-weighted assets associated with the first loss. So that's why of the full even though there's 160 billion, that's covered, there's only 144 billion that actually comes off once you take account of the loss retention in the scheme.

Losses up to 6% of that pool will be borne by us as a first loss, and then split 90/10. And we're paying, actually, two kinds of fees. The explicit fee is 2% of the gross pool, which is paid up front although in our accounts, will be amortized over seven years. In addition to that, we are being asked to give up tax relief in the UK in relation to our current deferred tax asset, which is about £5 billion, and any losses that we might make over the next two or three years before returning to profitability in the UK. And so – who knows the real value of that tax give-up and it's still to be worked through, it's of the details that remains the source of, let's say, controversy between the parties. But the NPV of that depends very much, a) on what losses we make and how much increases, and then how quickly we'll be able to use it over the next 10, 20 years whatever it would be; but that de facto has the impact of probably doubling the fee from the stated 2%; but you can come up with your own numbers as to what you think it does relative the fee.

Now, the other important bits of the scheme is, in a sense, the capital side and that is to say that we are issuing to the government B shares, which fall into, in a sense, three parts. One, B shares to pay for the fee, which is £6.5 billion. Secondly, a £13 billion issuance of B shares and I'll explain what's that's for in a second; and we have an option to draw down a further £6 billion should, in our judgment, we need it for capital purposes as we go through whatever the downturn is bringing to us.

Now, let me talk about, if you like, the impact of all of this and why we're doing and how it all works. On the pro forma, the risk-weighted assets change pro forma is obviously straightforward, it's a 144 billion change or roughly 25%. There are few moving pieces in the Core Tier 1 and that's also one of the reasons why we need some additional capital up front. The Core Tier 1 clearly goes up by the amount of B shares that we issue because the B shares are designed to count as Core Tier 1 as the FSA has confirmed. But the regulatory treatment of the Insurance is that 50% of the first loss piece needs to be deducted from Core Tier 1 capital, subject to a cap of 4% of the risk-weighted assets that are being protected. And so putting that crudely in numbers, there is roughly a £6 billion deduction from Core Tier 1 as a function of the way the FSA will count for the risk-weighted asset relief that they give on the other side and that creates a capital hole. Clearly, as we go through in subsequent years as this thing unwinds there will be various movements.

The amortization of the fee will hit Core Tier 1, because that doesn't hit on day one, that hits over the next seven years. As we make losses under the first loss piece, then those losses hit Core Tier 1, but half of them are offset by the deduction that you take up front in Core Tier 1 from the FSA 50% allocation. So there's quite a few sort of moving parts in how that will play out in the next few years. But what it means is that although our Core Tier 1 ratio jumps to a rather attractively high level pro forma, that's misleadingly high, because we know over the next seven years 6.5 billion comes off that as the fee amortizes through but that's already – that's in a sense a commitment up front.

We know that if we go into this we have to wipe 5 billion off Core Tier 1 because of the deferred tax asset that would have to go if we went into it; and then clearly to the extent we take losses against the first loss piece there is a further deduction to Core Tier 1; and finally to the extent we lend more in the UK that's an increase in risk-weighted assets. So, all of those moving parts are why you need to start with an unusually high Core Tier 1 ratio if you want to be very resilient even if things get really bad in the next two or three years in terms of capital hits. And it's for that reason that an up front issuance of capital over and above the one that offsets the fee is needed to offset the write off of deferred tax assets and of the FSA immediate deductions against Core Tier 1, and then whatever you think is going to happen as we go forward.

Now I just – I'll come on to lending commitments in a moment. The characteristics of the B shares, and again what we have is a term sheet as opposed to detailed, if you like, terms and conditions that are still to be worked out. But they can be seen in quite different ways according to what perspective you want to take. They are designed in a liquidation to rank alongside ordinary shares. But in liquidation no one is very happy, so that's probably the least important way of thinking about them, but that's what gets in Core Tier 1 treatment. They are – in ordinary course, they will pay a 7% dividend, after tax dividend of course. Actually, it's a formula that's the higher off 7% or 250% of dividends announced on the ordinary shares and that's – and the detail of that is set out in the press release of the company minutes. So it's 7% or higher. And in a sense, that is in perpetuity unless certain things happen.

So if you just thought about that in wanting to decide what are these things worth, you have to decide what discount rate you want to apply relative the 7% and then you discount 7% in perpetuity to get to whatever value you think is the economic give, if you like, of that. Clearly, if you're the government funding at 3% you might see it in one way; if you were looking at the markets for preference shares you might think it was unbelievably cheap and a good deal for shareholders. There's a wide range of how you might think about that.

The preference share dividends, the dividends on the B shares are effectively what I'll call junior preference shares. In other words, they rank ahead of ordinaries in dividend priority but a bit behind preference shares. We can waive them, they're non-cumulative, although obviously the government which holds them also holds a majority of our ordinary shares.

Now, the other feature of these B shares is that they are convertible at the government's option into ordinary shares at a price of 50 p per share. There are few, if you like, conditions around that, that is to say that the government has agreed that it won't take its voting above 75% and so therefore, in reality if they converted they'd have to convert and sell, thereby increasing the float and clearly if they converted prior to the share price being above 50 p they'd take a loss in doing it.

And so in thinking through the economics of that, again there are two quite different perspectives you can take. If we do a fully diluted calculation assuming that they convert on day one, with our share price yesterday at 20 p, we'll see where it ends today, then obviously a conversion price at 50 p is an incredibly good deal for shareholders relative to what would be available in the market and would mean that these capital instruments would be in a sense worth a big discount to face in terms of the value of ordinary shareholders of this capital.

On the other hand if you want to think about it different way, the government can collect 7% every year until such time as the share price is at 50 p and then convert and treat that as the maturity of its bond as it were in having the 7% bond, albeit with the risk characteristics associated with very, very junior preferred. And so in just trying to think through what this means for shareholders, there is actually quite a wide range of ways of thinking about the economic interests and subordination of shareholders to either the 7% cash flow streams or to the conversion, and it gives rise to the ability to have quite different perspectives on how dilutive this is of shareholders. I believe that in all scenarios this is cheap insurance and the right thing for us to do, but that is quite a different thing than saying it's a shareholder bonanza, it is not.

The situation that we face if the economic downturn is tough and lots of the first loss is required does, in effect, dilute ordinary shareholders interest in book value below these shares because of the 7% preference dividend. So you, I just urge you to think it through. I think no one will come to the conclusion other than it's a good deal, but you can come to quite a lot of different conclusions in terms of the end value, if you like, of what the ordinary shareholders have today.

Along with this is UK lending commitments. We have committed to increase lending relative to our '09 plan.
